frameDefinitions: An Executioner punishes an individual (Executed) with death as a consequence of some action of the Evaluee (the Reason).
A Prisoner is punished for committing a Crime by being confined to a Prison for a specified period of time.
In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
A former Member of a Group ceases to be a member as a result of the action of an Authority within the Group.
In this frame, a Communicator judges the Addressee and then communicates that appraisal directly to the Addressee.
A Killer or Cause causes the death of the Victim.
frameExamples: He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
The priest <t>excommunicated</t> Henry from the church.
The principal <t>rebuked</t> the student for cheating on the exam.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Executioner</fen> is the individual who performs the execution.
The <fen>Executed</fen> is the person who is killed by the <fen>Executioner</fen> in retribution for the crime that the <fen>Executed</fen> was convicted of.
When the execution occurs.
Where the execution takes place.
The <fen>Prisoner</fen> is held in custody as a punishment for having committed a crime.
The facility where the <fen>Prisoner</fen> is held.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Prisoner</fen> is in prison.
This role identifies the general <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Prisoner</fen> is held captive.
The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The person who used to belong to a <fen>Group</fen>.
A set of people standing in a semi-permanent relationship together.
An empowered subset of the <fen>Group</fen> which decides to expel its former <fen>Member</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Member</fen> is excluded.
The Place where the <fen>Member</fen> is excluded.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates a judgment to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> is jduged by the <fen>Communicator</fen> and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject on which the <fen>Addressee</fen> is being judged.
The <fen>Reason</fen> is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
The <fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
An action or entity under the control of the <fen>Communicator</fen> that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> berates or compliments the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> admonishes the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The person or sentient entity that causes the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The living entity that dies as a result of the killing.
An inanimate entity or process that causes the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The method or action that the <fen>Killer</fen> or <fen>Cause</fen> performs resulting in the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The device used by the <fen>Killer</fen> to bring about the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The point or period of time within which the <fen>Victim</fen> is killed.
The location where the death took place.
listRoleExamples: The truth is, <fex>we</fex> have all put them to death.
<fex>He</fex> was to be hanged in the morning.
I 'm afraid that <fex>I</fex> was expelled from the Society after they found I endorsed him.
Giles bemoaned his expulsion <fex>from the Future Farmers of America</fex>
The teacher scolded the children <fex>about their meessy cookie eating</fex>.
The principal rebuked the student <fex>for cheating on the exam</fex>.
Though she had killed him so long ago, she could still see his jeering <fex>smile</fex>.
She complimented me <fex>almost every morning</fex> on my smart starched shirts.
We were scolded <fex>in the kitchen</fex> by the biggest cook you've ever seen.
<fex>The rockslide</fex> killed nearly half of the climbers.
The flood exterminated the rats <fex>by cutting off access to food</fex>.
It's difficult to suicide <fex>with only a pocketknife</fex>.
There is no evidence that the royal family was killed <fex>during the destruction</fex> at this site.
Apparently there were two murders <fex>in Atherton</fex> in one week.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: La Question du meurtre rituel chez les Juifs
Vol. 14. New York: Robert Appleton Company
the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes
Etudes de critique et d'histoire religieuse"
the second half of the thirteenth century
